results.title: The French Revolution: the Bastille
results.creator_credit: Jean Becker, Victor Vicas and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description: Focusing on the fall of the Bastille, shows how a weak, bankrupt king’s efforts to raise money unleashed the first total revolution in history. Amid the extravagance of his court, Louis XVI is warned that he must choose between the demands of the nobility and bourgeoise if he expects to raise taxes in the Estates General. Throughout France, bread is scarce. Mass hunger is inflamed by the aristocrats’ resurgence and by bourgeois talk of equality. When order breaks down in the Paris streets, Louis sides with the nobles and sends troops into the city, and the poor react by turning on that symbol of royal power, the Bastille.

results.title: The French Revolution: death of the old regime
results.creator_credit: George Vicas, Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and National Broadcasting Company
results.brief_description: This film is a combination of live-action scenes with pictorial and sculptural masterpieces of the period. It recreates the chaotic events of the last days of the Old Regime in France. The rebellion of the Third Estate, the storming of the Bastille, the transfer of power from Versailles to Paris. With the establishment of the constitutional monarchy in 1789, the ideals of Liberty, Equality and Fraternity, replaced the “divine rights” and special privileges of the Old Regime. Narrated by Michael Redgrave.

results.title: The French Revolution: birth of a new France
results.creator_credit: George Vicas and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Beginning with the political conflict between leaders who felt that the revolution had gone too far and others who felt it had not gone far enough, this film examines the forces that shaped the Republic (for example, the film explains the opposition of the nobles and the clergy and the sense of conflict within the king and the rise of radical groups). With the failure of committee rule the leaders turned for support to the army and Napoleon Bonaparte and the revolution ended as it began, with one man rule. However the popular idea of sovereignty lived to change the face of Europe. Narrated by Michael Redgrave .

results.title: The French Revolution
results.brief_description: By re-enacting the experiences of M Roget, lawyer and member for the Third Estate, this film offers a brief history of the Revolution, from 1789 to Napoleon. Depicts the calling of the Estates General, formation of the National Assembly of the Third Estate, the discontentment and violence of the Parisian mobs. Follows events leading to The Terror and the final overthrow of the monarchy.

results.title: The French lieutenant's woman [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Karel Reisz, Leon Clore and Juniper Films
results.brief_description: Based on the brilliant novel by John Fowles and with a screenplay written by Harold Pinter, ‘The French Lieutenant’s woman’ is at once a classic Victorian love story and an ironic look at an age of double-standard morality. Sarah Woodruff’s chance meeting with Charles Smithson, a young man-about-town who subsequently discards his pretty young fiancee in a wave of passion, sets in motion a series of events that disrupts the quiet fishing and seaside village in England and profoundly affects the lives of its residents.

results.title: The French horn
results.creator_credit: Milton Ingerson, Malcolm Smith and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Basic Music Techniques”.
One of a series of films designed to assist the musician and music lover. In the film professional musicians demonstrate total range, method of playing and care of the French Horn.

results.title: The French Foreign Legion
results.creator_credit: Michael du Monceau, Mathieu Mazza, Adler Enterprises and Newsgroup
results.brief_description: This video covers the history of the French Foreign Legion, an army of mercenaries whose sense of honour and loyalty transcends national boundaries and commands respect as one of the world’s elite fighting forces. The Legionnaire’s loyalty is to the corps and not to France. They are often loathed by the French as unwelcome foreigners but equally, Legionnaires are considered useful for fighting and dying on behalf of the French in their colonial wars in Africa, Vietnam and various other French colonies across the world. More than 35,000 Legionnaires have died in battle with 8,000 alone being killed at the siege of Dien Bien Phu in Vietnam in 1954. The men who make up the French Foreign Legion are an enigma, often hated and despised for their mercenary attitude by some but highly respected for their fighting skills and effectiveness in battle, particularly guerilla warfare by others - all dependent upon your political and social point of view. Includes interviews, newsreels, stills, historic film footage of many of the battles fought in the 20th century around the world and rare behind-the-scenes footage of Legionnaires in training and in combat including frontline footage during Operation Desert Storm in the Gulf. Narrated by Jackson Bain. Contains some b&w footage.

results.title: The French explorers
results.creator_credit: Crawley Films and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Discusses French entry into the age of exploration. Tells of Cartier’s search for the Northwest Passage in 1534, and depicts Champlain’s 1603 expedition to the St. Lawrence River. Also shows the founding of Quebec and immigration of missionaries and traders.

results.title: The French doors
results.brief_description: A man is renovating his home and adds a set of French doors to the house. When he wakes the next morning the world has taken a dramatic turn into the unknown.
